samples.situation: I don't know what to do. I need to get a job and I have a lot of student debt.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Yea, I think that's true. Other people say that I am a quitter

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: They say I quit everything

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Have you gone and smoke to your local job centers? They can often times find suitable jobs or even creative suggestions that can utilize your skills and even grown them.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: No, I'm not aware of any local job centers around me. I mostly have been looking online at places like indeed.com

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I'm not sure what you mean by "job center," I guess, either

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Refusing to finish something that does not benefit your end goal isn't quitting its merely switching strategies to your personal end goal

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Oh, yea. That's a good reframe. I like that.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I suppose, I'm just getting older and wish I had better, more stable options available to me. All this education hasn't really left with me many hard skills, I feel

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I am from North Carolina and in every city there are job centers, you can look them up by that title, they have people there who can help you find work based on your personality and skills. as well helping with resumes, interveiws, computers, all kinds of things.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Interesting. I guess I can look into that. I am from Ohio. That's not bad advice.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I am somewhat kicking myself for paying so much money on education that wasn't really worth that much. I guess there isn't much I can do about that, though

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Im sorry you feel that way but education is never a wasted effort it can only make you level up even if you choose not to actively use what you acquire. Its always nice to have a big back up arsenal so you have options when something you want does turn up.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Im really glad that suggestion might be helpful for you.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Have you checked to see if any of the credits you have earned already are transferable to another degree you may find of interest?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I suppose there can be truth in that. I had a friend say that as well, that education is never a wasted effort. I agree sometimes. I should have thought about the program more before I went into it, but ah, oh well. Nothing I can do about it, now.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: No, it wouldn't be transferable.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I have though about doing some grad school for something bio related. I don't know.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I'm 30 now and getting burned out, to be honest

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Anyway, you've said a lot of nice and helpful things. I don't want to take too much time from you. After all, you won your bonus money. But, I really do appreciate you talking to me.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker

generated_dialog.content: Those are valuable skills! Maybe you could focus on creating a resume that highlights those strengths and consider practicing your pitches to feel more confident.

samples.situation: I am worried about failing my college math exams and being kicked out of school.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: What do you think will happen if I fail this test?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Sometimes it is not about the amount of studying, but the way you study. I like reading my textbooks and highlighting the important parts and then rewriting them so they become ingrained in me. But let us not jump the gun, you haven't failed anything.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Very true.  Thanks for reminding me.  I think I worry more about the outcome than I need too.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Don't forget to breathe. Exams are stressful but I would suggest don't cram everything to the last minute. Usually the hour before the exam, I do something else.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Very good advice.  Any suggestions on what I can do?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Stay calm, believe in yourself, start your studying early so you are not cramming everything in the last few days.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Great Advice.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: But, in the one hour prior to the exam, do you have any advice on something I can do to calm my nerves?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Walk outside, away from the students waiting for their tests.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Wonderful suggestion

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Thank you for your help.  I think I will go walk now.  Best regards.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Is there anything else I can help you with?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: No.  Thank you.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Goodnight and good luck.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, I've been practicing a few math problems every day. It helps a little, but I still feel anxious.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That's a great approach. It sounds like you're putting in the effort. Can you think of any specific topics that are causing you the most stress?

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: I think it's mostly the word problems. They always confuse me, and I struggle to know how to approach them.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: Itâ€™s completely normal to find certain areas challenging. Maybe you could try breaking them down into smaller steps or even discussing them with a study group?

samples.situation: I dont know what to do with out her.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: That is a long time. Event though she was your rock,  just know that you will eventually find someone new and this hurt will be no more.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: But im not sure how to survive in the time being.  my life will be a disaster.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I can feel your pain,  i have had similar experience and it took quite a while to move on, but know that this too will pass

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I dont have the time to do all she did to maintain my house.  What am i supposed to do now she is gone.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: There was a time when I had a breakup that left me feeling like it was the end of the world,  but i am fine now and  so would you.  Take some long walks but he sure to socially distance and try meeting new friends online and just talk.  That will help

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: But what about my dishes, and bathroom cleaning that she did, and i dont have time to do?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: My house is already starting to look terrible since she has left.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: think about it,  the added exercise will help you from getting lonely with her not being around

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: But  i have never done laundry.  My mother did it when i lived with her. and i moved out from my mother to live with my girlfriend. How am i gonna do my laundry? I've never done it.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: If you focus too much on the break up,  you will have a hard time getting over her so try to do some fun activities that you can enjoy alone  so that you are safe.  You can search youtube on how to do laundry and other chores,  you will be ok

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Thank you for your advice.  It probably isnt that hard. I just am nervous about trying to do it myself for the first time.  Its starting to pile up now.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Don't be nervous,  Just take some time to learn the house chores and you'll be fine

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: It'll be new, but i guess i could at least try.  But i miss her so much.  I dont think i can ever find someone else like her.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: You will find that someone. Hope I was able to make you feel a bit better.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: You are very positive.  I wish i had your positivity.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Think of the glass half full.   You will do well.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, I find myself staring at the laundry and feeling overwhelmed. It just reminds me how much I relied on her.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: It's completely normal to feel that way. You've shared a lot of responsibilities with her, and now you're facing the challenge alone. Have you thought about tackling one small load at a time?

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: That makes sense. Maybe I could start with just a few items instead of everything at once. It feels less intimidating.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: Absolutely! Starting small can really help. Remember, it's okay to take your time with things and ask for advice if you need it. You're doing great by being proactive.

samples.situation: I am very scare of this pandemic call COVID-19

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I am really afraid here I don't know what to do

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: As for the pandemic, if you know no one who has died, I wouldn't worry about it. The CDC has no reported deaths of anyone healthy. People who are unhealthy die, not the healthy, and people who are sick ALREADY are the ones who die. If you are relatively healthy, then you are good to go. Do things to protect your health. What are you eating? What are you drinking? Are you talking to friends and getting social life? Are you getting fresh air? Thinking good thoughts?  Or are you living in fear when you are not going to a lot of funerals.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: It is well documented that our immune system is affected by our mental state, so it is important that you care for your health. Focusing on the negativity of the pandemic will bring you down. Focusing on being healthy and taking care of your mind, soul, spirit and body will help build up your immunity and make you strong.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I don't like the noise of ambulance at all any time I see one I don't feel happy

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I can understand an ambulance sound is hard to hear, but even that can be turned around. You can pray for the person, then switch your mind off. If you focus on the negative, you will stay negative. If you do what you can (pray) then there is nothing else to do. Focusing on the negative will depress you.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: One thing I did to help with depression is keep a checklist of things to do when I felt down:  call a friend, call a loved one to encourage THEM, go for a walk, eat fruits and veggies, read a book, go for a bike ride, etc.  Things like that, then I chose to do those things despite how I felt. Doing those things helped my mood TREMENDOUSLY>

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Feelings follow thoughts. If you think negative thoughts, you will feel negative. If you think positive thoughts, you will feel positive. Sometimes this takes time, but it works.  Just because you feel sad doesn't mean you should just do nothing, a person can TALK their way out of sadness and choose to do something different.

prefix_dialog.content: I am glad you were able to talk about how this is affecting you. I think many people are affected. samples.situation: Losing Job

It requires more money and more management, and quite a few people are very happy to not do either of those things for ostensibly higher quality workforce.

Students love a good live subject :-)

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: You should explore what resources your city/county/province may offer for job seekers.  It is in the best interest of almost every community that its members have have jobs and feel useful, so you may find some valuable information and maybe some connections.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Oh!  And what I always tell everyone who is looking for a job:  Apply UP!  Don't ever think is something above your level.  Apply UP!  They may admire your temerity and invite you for an interview just to see who you think you are :-)

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: My spirits are going up just having this conversation and looking forward to the community outreach. Hopefully it helps lift this gloom that has been over me for months. I loved my previous job but due to bad management it was taking a toll on everyone employed.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I am glad to hear you are feeling a little better!  Yes, bad management is so toxic.  Even with great coworkers in a job you love, horrible management can ruin it quickly.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker

samples.situation: I always feel like the way I look does not live up to the expectations of those close to me. This makes me very anxious when I go to meet with them.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Hello

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Hello! How are you doing?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I am anxious

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I'm sorry to hear that. What is the cause of your anxiety?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: My friends and my family place a lot of value on how one looks. Every time I meet with them they have a comment on how I should improve on something. It makes me stressed out because I feel like I am not good enough.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I am sorry you are having to deal with this. Are you concerned about your own looks because you constantly hear this feedback from those close to you?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Yes. I feel that I am not thin enough, pretty enough, that my clothes are not nice enough etc

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I myself have gone through similar feelings when I was a teenager. I had body image issues for the longest time and my way of resolving it was through proper diet and exercise. Are you happy with how you look personally irrespective of what others opinions are?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: It is hard to feel ok when I keep hearing that I am missing something. I don't even think I need to lose weight. It is just that my friends think model thin is what beauty is. I would have to starve myself to achieve that.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: If you are comfortable with your weight then why are you so concerned with what everyone around you says or thinks?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: Because they are the people I spend time with. I want to be accepted and I want them to like me.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: It sounds like you care more about what others think of you than how you feel about yourself.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I wish I could not care about what they think but I do. I don't know how to not let their opinions not bother me

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Have you ever tried affirmations or heard of this before?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: No. What is that?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Affirmations are positive statements you think about yourself. What I like to do when I'm feeling really anxious is say three positive things/attributes I feel about myself over and over again until my anxiety dissipates. Do you think that could help you feel more positively about what those closest to you are saying so much with regards to looks?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I could try. Do I need to say positive things about my looks or can they be about other stuff?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Since you are stating that you are concerned about how you look, you should just find a few positive statements with regards to your looks you think about yourself and repeat them. So if you don't think you need to lose weight, you can say something like, "I like my weight." or "I don't need to lose weight." If you think you are beautiful or pretty, you can say "I am beautiful." My three affirmations I use for myself are: I am beautiful, smart, and funny. I say this over and over again until my anxiety has left me.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, I've noticed that sometimes when I try to affirm myself, I still feel the old doubts creeping back in.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: Itâ€™s completely normal to have lingering doubts, especially when theyâ€™ve been part of your thoughts for a long time. Can you share what specific doubts come to mind when youâ€™re trying to affirm yourself?

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: I often think about what my friends said before, like how they compare me to others and say I should dress differently.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That sounds really challenging. It might be helpful to recognize that those comments reflect their opinions and not necessarily the truth about your worth. How do you think you could remind yourself of your own value when those doubts surface?

I never had a voice for myself. They basically

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content:
So they know that I don't share their beliefs
?

prefix_dialog.content: No, i think that should be personal to you, i would not suggest you hurting or making them see you as a disappointment

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: It's confusing because I want to be honest but I'm scared of how they might react.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That makes sense; itâ€™s tough to balance honesty with the fear of their reaction. Maybe you could start by sharing small things that feel safe to discuss?

samples.situation: I have dealt with depression around this time of the year since i was 17.  I am now 37.  My cousin got killed in a car accident on Dec 29th  at the age of 14.  Then 18 years later on Jan 3rd I lost my boyfriend in a car accident.  I struggle around the holidays even worse now than I  did before.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Hi there, how are you?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I am doing ok.  How are you?

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. What are you seeking support for today?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I have been struggling for motivation to do anything the past couple weeks.  This is a really hard time of year for me.  I lost my cousin in a car accident at the age of 14 in a car accident coming up on 20 years this year.  We were very close.  I was 17 at the time.  Her was an alcoholic and my parents raised her a majority of her life.  Then 3 years ago 5 days after her death anniversary I lost my boyfriend at the age of 32 in a car accident.  I dread the holidays.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you are describing a strong association between the holiday season and loss of loved ones. This leads to less of a desire to engage in typical holiday events. Does that sound right?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: You are exactly right.  The year my cousin got killed her mom was hungover so I went and picked up my cousin and her little brother to take them to our grandparents house for Christmas dinner.  She died 4 days later on Dec 29th.  And my boyfriend it was his first day back to work after the New Year.  He died on Jan 3rd.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I usually go all out for the holidays to try to hide my depression every year.  This year I just can't bring myself to enjoy them.  I have even bought one christmas present.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I can see why this time of year is difficult for you. Trying to hide depression can be a challenge. Rather than hiding the sadness or grieving feelings, some people find relief in acknowledging and sharing these feelings with family members who may relate. Do you ever share these feelings with your cousin or grandparents that you mentioned?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: My cousin doesn't live around here and we have never been real close.  He is alot younger than me.  We just never had the connection like his sister and I did.  And both my grandparents have passed away.  Grandpa has been gone for 12 years and Grandma has been gone for 4 now.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: My family has always been really good about talking about our loses. Things just will never be the same.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I understand. When losses are experienced it is a great change in many aspects of our lives.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Are there any aspects of the holidays that bring you joy? Maybe holiday music, movies, bright snow (if there is snow where you live), or seeing joy on someone's face when you give them a great gift?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: They say it gets easier. And I agree it does.  Things just have changed so much.  I miss how life was before I lost them.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I understand - and it is normal to feel that way. When we lose someone who brought us happiness, it is only natural to miss them and their company.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, I've been thinking a lot about how my boyfriend used to love this time of year. He really enjoyed decorating and making the holidays special.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: It sounds like those happy memories with your boyfriend make this time even more challenging for you. How do you feel when you think about those moments?

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: I feel a mix of happiness and sadness. I cherish those memories, but they also remind me of what I'm missing now.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That's a very understandable way to feel. It can be comforting to hold onto those positive memories while also allowing yourself to feel the sadness. Would you want to find ways to honor those memories during the holidays?

samples.situation: I am at my first semester in a doctoral program and have a lot to do at once and have been feeling very anxious in the past few weeks.

samples.situation: Every few nights at nighttime, I get severely depressed and I don't know why

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

prefix_dialog.content: Especially when the sun starts going down sooner, it can seem like we have less time, and as if things are closing in upon us.

prefix_dialog.content: There are a few strategies you could use to combat that.  Personally, I try to soak in as much sunlight as possible before it goes down.  Sometimes that will mean moving your work space, maybe getting up earlier to have a cup of coffee in the sunrise, maybe it's scheduling breaks into your day where you specifically get some vitamin D.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter

I then exhale slowly through my nose and repeat for about 10 minutes. It can be very calming.

samples.situation: My (ex)fiancÃ© and I recently broke up, but we're still spending a great deal of time together, and we both say we're not sure if our relationship is 100% "done" and agreed to tell each other if we start dating other people. prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content:
That would definitely add to the distress of the situation to have a weird surprise like that. It doesn't really seem like your fault that you were there but it is unfortunate nonetheless. Have you tried talking to h
im yet?

samples.situation: I feel I am failing in my graduate program. I feel that I am not good enough to earn my doctorate degree.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: School is the start of the problem. I know that if I quit I can still be successful elsewhere but I also feel if I quit I will let my wife and kids down who were willing to leave family and friends to follow me to the school I wanted to go to.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I understand what you are going through. It is as if you are being pulled in two directions, but are not sure which is the best option at the given moment. I think it is great that you wanted to go back to school, but if your heart is not in it, then it may not be what you should continue pursuing.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: I know I want this though. I enjoy what I do and what I would do for my career if I graduate. I mainly feel inadequate. I feel that I am not good enough. I am willing to do whatever it takes but fear that whatever my "best" is may not be good enough.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: I can feel your worries when you speak about your anxiety, and I am hoping we can find a way to approach your feelings. Do you think there was a specific instance that is causing doubts within yourself or is it in your nature to self-doubt?

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: It is in my nature to self doubt. Additionally, I have had a few bumps in the road during my program and struggle to pick myself up after those bumps. For example, I am on academic probation and have a certain expectation over the next few months that I have to hit to stay in the program due to struggles in previous classes. I am reaching the bar just fine, according to those that I work with, and often feel I am doing quite well but occasionally I start to panic and think that I am not doing as well as I think that I am and start to spiral

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: This has also been a past struggle of mine, and I think it partially stems from the bar we set so high for ourselves. We obviously cannot reach the top right away, but have to work our way up. Often times, when facing an obstacle, such as a bad grade, we might retreat further down the path due to fear that it will keep happening. I know that I personally had a tendency to think of my family and friends who I feel are dependent on me or comparing myself with others when the only person we should think of in these instances is ourself. When making progress, tiny steps upward matter more than you think. But when we take a step backward, we cannot fall back down to the starting point by letting our doubts pile upon one another.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: That is a really good point and helpful. Thank you!

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Of course, I am happy to help! I have noticed that letting yourself celebrate a good grade can be really helpful to feel that you are enough and making good progress. But when things do go south, because life certainly happens, we must stay in the present and live life like we usually would, with a drive that we are going to push harder against whatever we have to face next.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content: That is exactly right. I need to focus more on what progress has been made and not on what progress hasn't been made yet because there is still time to make that progress.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: Exactly! I also suggest if you are having doubts, talk it out with someone like your partner or a close friend. They can often provide a pick me up you didn't even know you needed. More than anything, give yourself credit and relax. Take some time to just breathe and release the tension. I guarantee it will leave you feeling refreshed and fulfilled for the next tasks you have to face. I believe you can do this and I feel that you believe it too, which is amazing. As often as it is said, believing in yourself is truly the best foundation to achieve your goals.

prefix_dialog.speaker: seeker
prefix_dialog.content:
Thanks for the advice and believing in me. This has been challenging and your words of encouragement give me hope for the future
.

prefix_dialog.speaker: supporter
prefix_dialog.content: You're welcome. It was great talking to you. Your future is bright, and I wish you all of the luck for the endeavors to get you there.

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker
generated_dialog.content: Also, Iâ€™ve been trying to practice a bit of mindfulness to manage the anxiety. It helps sometimes, but I still worry about how Iâ€™ll perform in my classes.

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: That's a great step! Mindfulness can be really helpful in grounding yourself. How do you feel it has impacted your day-to-day thoughts about the program?

generated_dialog.speaker: seeker

generated_dialog.speaker: supporter
generated_dialog.content: It's completely normal for those worries to come back, especially given your circumstances. Have you considered speaking with an academic advisor? They might provide additional support and resources to help you stay on track.
